articles.headline: U.S. Accuses S. & P. of Fraud in Suit on Loan Bundles
articles.snippet: The Justice Department has filed civil fraud charges in federal court in Los Angeles against Standard & Poor’s over its ratings of mortgage-related securities.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department has filed civil fraud charges in federal court in Los Angeles against Standard & Poor’s over its ratings of mortgage-related securities.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department filed civil fraud charges late on Monday against the nation’s largest credit-ratings agency, Standard & Poor’s, accusing the firm of inflating the ratings of mortgage investments and setting them up for a crash when the financial crisis struck.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Bet on U.S. Pays Off for Germany’s Carmakers
articles.snippet: The American auto market’s recovery has also been a boon for Daimler, BMW and Volkswagen, which have invested heavily in the United States.
articles.abstract: The American auto market’s recovery has also been a boon for Daimler, BMW and Volkswagen, which have invested heavily in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was only a few years ago that some economists were arguing that Europe was “decoupling” from its long dependence on trade with the United States and predicting that the Continent’s future lay with the so-called tiger economies of Asia.

articles.headline: Dell Nears a Buyout of More Than $23 Billion
articles.snippet: The potential deal would include financial muscle from Microsoft and the investment firm Silver Lake.
articles.abstract: The potential deal would include financial muscle from Microsoft and the investment firm Silver Lake.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dell Inc. neared an agreement on Monday to sell itself to a group led by its founder and the investment firm Silver Lake for more than $23 billion, people briefed on the matter said, in what would be the biggest buyout since the financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Hand of U.S. Is Seen in Halting General’s Rise in Mexico
articles.snippet: Gen. Moisés García Ochoa was blocked from becoming defense minister after American officials expressed their concern that he had ties to drug traffickers.
articles.abstract: Gen. Moisés García Ochoa was blocked from becoming defense minister after American officials expressed their concern that he had ties to drug traffickers.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Mexico’s military staged its annual Independence Day parade in September, spectators filled the main square of Mexico City to cheer on the armed forces. Nearly 2,000 miles away in Washington, American officials were also paying attention.
articles.byline: By Ginger Thompson, Randal C. Archibold and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Seeking a Company’s Elusive Sales Data
articles.snippet: Uncertainty over who buys Herbalife products has left shares of the company vulnerable to wild market swings in recent months.
articles.abstract: Uncertainty over who buys Herbalife products has left shares of the company vulnerable to wild market swings in recent months.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prominent Wall Street investors are arguing acrimoniously over whether the nutritional supplements company Herbalife is a pyramid scheme.

articles.headline: A Billion-Dollar Club, and Not So Exclusive
articles.snippet: An unexpectedly large number of high-technology start-ups are valued at $1 billion or more.
articles.abstract: An unexpectedly large number of high-technology start-ups are valued at $1 billion or more.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The number of privately held Silicon Valley start-ups that are worth more than $1 billion shocks even the executives running those companies.

articles.headline: Waiting Times at Ballot Boxes Draw Scrutiny
articles.snippet: With studies suggesting that long lines at the polls cost Democrats hundreds of thousands of votes in November, party leaders are beginning a push to make voting and voter registration easier.
articles.abstract: With studies suggesting that long lines at the polls cost Democrats hundreds of thousands of votes in November, party leaders are beginning a push to make voting and voter registration easier.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With studies suggesting that long lines at the polls cost Democrats hundreds of thousands of votes in November, party leaders are beginning a push to make voting and voter registration easier, setting up a likely new conflict with Republicans over a deeply polarizing issue.

articles.headline: Target Date Funds at Fidelity Fall Short of Rivals
articles.snippet: Investors have flocked to so-called target date funds, but the retirement products are not as worry-free as the big investment companies advertise.
articles.abstract: Investors have flocked to so-called target date funds, but the retirement products are not as worry-free as the big investment companies advertise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fidelity Investments is the giant of “target date” mutual funds, one of the hottest ideas in 401(k) plans.

articles.headline: Dell in $24 Billion Deal to Go Private
articles.snippet: Dell announced that it had agreed to go private in a $24.4 billion deal led by its founder and the investment firm Silver Lake, in the biggest leveraged buyout since the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Dell announced that it had agreed to go private in a $24.4 billion deal led by its founder and the investment firm Silver Lake, in the biggest leveraged buyout since the financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Quentin Hardy
